title: Front Fork - Removal

body.body: Warning - General - Stabilise Motorcycle - including DO NOT support on non integral parts
Make sure the motorcycle is stabilised and adequately supported.
Do not support the motorcycle on any ancillary component, the exhaust system or any other non structural parts of the motorcycle frame.
A correctly supported motorcycle will help prevent it from falling.
Failure to follow the advice above could result in serious injury or death.
Raise and remove front wheel DTC; D72; DE; DT3; DT4; DU; DU3; DU4; DUY; DTB; DUB; DUC
Raise and support the front of the motorcycle.

metadata.ModelsTaxonomyLink: DUC; DTB; DUB; DTC; DU4; DT4; D72; DU3; DT3; DE; DUY; DU

body.body: Never allow the brake calipers to hang on the brake hoses as this may damage the hoses. A damaged brake hose can cause a reduction in braking efficiency leading to loss of motorcycle control and an accident.
Front Fork Remove DTC; D72; DA2; DB; DB2; DBX; DT3; DT4; DU; DU3; DU4; DUY; DUB; DTB; DUC
Note the routing of the ABS wheel speed sensor harness for installation.
There is a shim between the ABS wheel speed sensor and the front fork leg.
Release the fixing and detach the ABS wheel speed sensor from the left hand fork leg, and collect the shim.
If the forks are to be dismantled, loosen the fork top caps.
Loosen the upper yoke pinch bolt.
If both forks are being removed, ensure the headlight and bracket assembly is securely supported.
Do not allow the headlight and bracket assembly to hang by its harness.
Loosen the lower yoke pinch bolt and slide the fork down through the yokes. Discard the pinch bolt.
Care must be taken when removing the forks, to ensure that the outer surfaces do not become scratched.
Remove the forks from the lower yoke.

search: Front Fork - Removal
Make sure the motorcycle is stabilised and adequately supported.
Do not support the motorcycle on any ancillary component, the exhaust system or any other non structural parts of the motorcycle frame.
A correctly supported motorcycle will help prevent it from falling.
Failure to follow the advice above could result in serious injury or death.
Raise and support the front of the motorcycle.
Front Wheel - Removal

Never allow the brake calipers to hang on the brake hoses as this may damage the hoses. A damaged brake hose can cause a reduction in braking efficiency leading to loss of motorcycle control and an accident.
Remove the front mudguard (see
Front Mudguard - Removal
Note the routing of the ABS wheel speed sensor harness for installation.
There is a shim between the ABS wheel speed sensor and the front fork leg.
Release the fixing and detach the ABS wheel speed sensor from the left hand fork leg, and collect the shim.
Fixing
Front ABS wheel speed sensor
ABS wheel speed sensor harness
Shim
If the forks are to be dismantled, loosen the fork top caps.
Loosen the upper yoke pinch bolt.
Upper yoke pinch bolt
If both forks are being removed, ensure the headlight and bracket assembly is securely supported.
Do not allow the headlight and bracket assembly to hang by its harness.
Loosen the lower yoke pinch bolt and slide the fork down through the yokes. Discard the pinch bolt.
Pinch bolt
Lower yoke
Headlight bracket
Care must be taken when removing the forks, to ensure that the outer surfaces do not become scratched.
Remove the forks from the lower yoke.
